legal_regulatory.title: Legal and Regulatory
findings: LEGAL AND REGULATORY AI POLICY AND REGULATION The law 20.212 of November 2023 included in its articles 74 and 75 specific provisions for the governance and regulatory capacity of AI in the country.

Article 74 entrusts AGESIC with the task of designing and developing a National data and Artificial Intelligence Strategy based on international standards, for the public and private spheres and emphasizing that matters concerning personal data processing are mandated by the existing Law 18.331 to b
Article 75 mandates AGESIC with the development of regulatory sandboxes to promote innovation in AI and data environments, with a multistakeholder emphasis.
Without these, AI regulation in Uruguay today has no mechanisms for ex-ante regulatory approaches on AI systems.
Other complementary policies and legislations bolster the regulatory framework concerning AI in Uruguay.
Law 18.331 (2008) on Personal Data Protection stands as a key pillar, providing guidelines for the collection, storage, and use of personal information, crucial in the AI normative context.

In terms of policies, Uruguay’s Digital Policy and the Uruguay Digital Agenda 2021-2025, ratified by Decree 134/021 (2021), offer a general framework for the country’s digital transformation, covering aspects that may indirectly impact AI regulation.

Also, the International Cooperation Policy of Uruguay for Sustainable Development 2030, endorsed by Decree 243/019 (2019), acknowledges the challenges arising from the swift evolution of AI and its impact on various socioeconomic aspects.
strengths: Furthermore, Uruguay has delineated a roadmap for AI through the implementation of the AI Strategy for Digital Government, established by AGESIC and unveiled in September 2020 following a public consultation process.
The AI Strategy for Digital Government has experienced significant progress in its implementation since its inception.

This iterative process of engagement and inclusion of diverse perspectives reflects the commitment to engaging with and considering input from various stakeholders, ensuring a comprehensive and inclusive approach in shaping the strategy (AGESIC, 2023d).
Since 2008 the country has enacted Law 18.331 for the protection of personal data.
Law 18.331 is a comprehensive instrument that enabled the country to achieve adequacy status with the European Union (2012/484/EU).
Institutionally, Uruguay’s responsible entity for data protection is the URCDP (Regulatory and Control Unit of Personal Data), established by Law 18.33 which operates with technical autonomy.

It annually collects statistical information related to compliance with formal obligations established in the law, such as database registrations, appointment of data protection delegates, etc (AGESIC, 2022f).
The URCDP’s powers are comprehensive, serving both advisory and supervisory roles (URCDP, n.d.a).
In tandem, the URCDP crafted a comprehensive Guide for Data Protection Impact Assessment (URCDP, 2020a), further augmenting the law’s application and practical implementation (AGESIC, n.d.c).
GOVERNMENT OPEN DATA Uruguay has established governmental open data policies through the National Open Data Strategy (AGESIC, 2022a).
gaps: These are significant developments to overcome existing shortcomings to the current regulatory governance scenario of Uruguay on AI, where accountability regimes linked to these technologies are yet to be developed, and the laws are essential for those developments.
However, the assessment of its effectiveness has been limited by the absence of specific impact indicators.
This is reflected in the lack of data or reports measuring the progress or achievements attained through the strategy’s implementation.
However, there are no budget allocations foreseen for the implementation of the Strategy in other state agencies, which calls for an area of opportunity.
IMPACT ASSESSMENT The current AI Strategy’s text does not include this requirement.

However, by incorporating the principles of personal data protection (Article 12 of Law 18.331, 2008) into the ‘Privacy by Design’ principle of the strategy, there is also an obligation for impact assessment regarding data protection when there is automated processing for profiling purposes.
While this law does not expressly stipulate indemnification procedures, recourse to provisions concerning damages in the Civil Code stands applicable in instances of infringement.
However, there are exceptions specified in articles 24, 25, and 26 of Law 18.331 (2008) regarding the creation, modification, or deletion of databases within certain public entities.
However, currently there is no information regarding the evaluation of the effectiveness of Uruguay’s national data exchange framework.
However, there has not been an evaluation of the effectiveness of Uruguay’s governmental open data policies.

social_cultural.title: Social and Cultural
findings: It encourages multistakeholder governance through consultative processes that are central to several public policy instruments in AI and other digital policies.
There are regulations, such as Law 19.691 (2018), focusing on promoting employment for people with disabilities which is also general and not exclusive to AI.
The General Education Law (Law 18.437, 2009) has provisions for educational inclusion and diversity.

There are no indigenous languages used in the country, and the presence of linguistic minorities through variations of Spanish with Portuguese specifically in the northern department of Artigas (Chargoñia, 2007) is not captured in online content nor in the training of AI systems.

Regarding the Electronic Participation Index (EPI) – which evaluates the extent to which a government provides information to its constituents, involves citizens in policy design, and empowers citizens in decision-making processes– the country scored 0.50 points in 2022, occupying the 61st position.
Uruguay’s case is not included in the IPSOS measurement on trust in AI and technology (IPSOS, 2022), nor do other relevant sources emerge for the national case (EDELMAN, 2022).
The media tends to have a more favorable stance toward the benefits of AI, while social media users are more skeptical and critical.

Nevertheless, when considering the sub-region grouping Chile, Argentina, and Uruguay, positive or neutral sentiments are far more prevalent than in other sub-regions and negative perceptions towards AI are the lowest in the region according to this study (ILIA, 2023).
strengths: Uruguay has a general regulation aimed at promoting diversity and inclusion in the workplace, the Comprehensive Law for Transgender Persons (Law 19.684, 2018), which is not specific for AI.

The Interinstitutional Forum for Women in Science, Innovation, and Technology (MIMCIT) was established in 2016 and remains dedicated to coordinating efforts, raising awareness, and conducting studies and publications on the matter in the country.
In relation to the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), Uruguay launched in 2022 a new bond into the global market indexed to climate change indicators (IDB, 2022).
gaps: SOCIAL AND CULTURAL DIVERSITY, INCLUSION AND EQUALITY The gender gap in internet usage in Uruguay shows that more women use the internet than men.
There are no measurements comparing the digital divide gap between urban and rural areas in Uruguay.

The Survey of Information and Communication Technologies Usage (EUTIC) measures the gap between Montevideo and the rest of the country (smaller urban areas inland and the rural environment, all grouped together).
This gap between Montevideo and other areas stands at 7%, with the capital having 95% access to internet (fixed or mobile) from home compared to 88% in the rest of the country (AGESIC, 2023a).
The implementation of these policies has significantly impacted the reduction of the digital gap, as observed in the survey EUTIC (AGESIC, 2023a).

In the 2023 Global Gender Gap Index, composed by four dimensions: Economic Participation and Opportunity, Educational Attainment, Health and Survival, and Political Empowerment Uruguay ranks 67th and has improved 5 places compared to the 2022 edition.

Figura 1 Figura 2 ### Page 23 22 The proportion of girls and boys studying sciences or mathematics and aspiring to work as professionals in STEM fields by the age of 30 shows that 47% of boys and 31.3% of girls have expressed their intention to work in this area, a gap of almost 15% according to the
Yet the gap between both groups’ performance is much lower, in PISA tests in science, where boys scored 428 points, while girls scored 424 (OECD, 2019).

While the country does not have a specific policy aimed at reducing the digital gender gap, it has over 20 years of sustained public policies on digital technologies for development with a long-standing commitment and consistency.
The implementation of these policies has significantly impacted the reduction of the digital gap, as observed in the survey EUTIC (AGESIC, 2023a).

scientific_educational.title: Scientific and Educational
findings: Through the Fiscal Credit instrument for companies engaging in R&D activities, in 2022, the Ministry of Economy and Finance allocated an amount of UYU 140,000,000 (approximately 3.6 million US dollars) granted under Law 19.739, which empowers the Executive Branch to grant fiscal credit to private la
RESEARCH OUTPUT The number of publications on AI and related topics amounted to 200 in 2023 (OECD.AI, 2023a).

This is nearly half the amount of Latvia, a country with a similar GDP and half the population of Uruguay, and is a third of Slovenia’s output, with a similar GDP and 35% less inhabitants, but it is nearly three times the total production of AI publications from Panama.
Systematic data regarding the number of per capita FAccT (Fairness, Accountability, and Transparency in AI) publications is unavailable.
There is no consolidated information on research centers that address AI issues.

ETHICAL AI RESEARCH Uruguay has hosted the KHIPU conference (Latin American Meeting on AI) for three consecutive years, serving as a non-profit platform aimed at fostering a community of stakeholders beyond AI system developers within the region.

The March 2023 edition developed the Montevideo Declaration on Artificial Intelligence, shedding light not only on the potential for development, but also on the associated risks of these technological tools (Marroquín et al., 2023).

Alongside AGESIC’s ongoing activities (which encompass more national-level initiatives), other events are organized, such as those orchestrated by URCDP, featuring guest speakers in the ‘Coffee Talks’ series engaging in discussions on AI concerning personal data protection and gender (URCDP, n.d.).
strengths: More recently, Ceibal launched in October 2023 a Framework for the teaching of artificial intelligence (Ceibal, 2023) for primary and middle education.

Regarding tertiary education programs that offer one or more modules on AI, a Ministry of Industry and Energy report ‘Uruguay Transforma’ (MIEM, 2019), identified 101 courses encompassing ‘advanced technologies’ (robotics, Artificial Intelligence, cloud computing, Internet of Things, 3D printing, an

Universities such as the Catholic University of Uruguay (UCU, n.d) and the University of Montevideo (UM, n.d.) supplement engineering programs with subjects comprehensive to a university student’s core education, encompassing ethics, deontology, and philosophical anthropology.
These programs promote the training and active participation of students leading projects in their educational center, aiming to address a problem related to their digital well-being.
The INEFOP, a public institute established in 2008, is primarily responsible for implementing professional training policies and enhancing employment for workers in the country.

In 2018-2019, a prospective report was conducted with support from ECLAC regarding automation and its employment impact in Uruguay, yet significant progress in this area has not been observed (OPP, 2019).
gaps: However, Uruguay does not have an estimation of public credits dedicated to research and development in AI.

Concerning research on AI ethics, the OECD.AI platform does not differentiate or specify research focused on AI Ethics, making it challenging to quantify the number of per capita publications solely dedicated to AI ethics within that dataset.
However, data on the number of AI patents granted per capita is currently unavailable.
However, there is a need for an assessment on the effectiveness of these policies, as it has not yet been conducted.
However, the effectiveness of this strategy has not been evaluated.

economic.title: Economic
findings: It is no wonder that so many governments, institutions and stakeholders across the world are claiming a different set of norms to steer the development of AI to improve humanity, distribute its benefits and lay proper guardrails for the many risks and challenges that it poses.

Different sectors, organizations and independent voices today seek to dispute a narrative about unfettered innovation that is no longer acceptable nor sustainable, which has been super-charged by the massive adoption of generative AI tools over the last couple of years.
UNESCO has a firm commitment to the role of ethics in the steering of AI systems.
It recognizes AI’s value in driving innovation in key sectors such as health, agriculture, education and science, among others.

Ever since we started with the process of the UNESCO Recommendation on the Ethics of AI, approved in November 2021 during the General Assembly by 193 countries we have been engaged in an open discussion about AI innovation within the boundaries of ethics.
The RAM is an invaluable tool that supports countries in the detection of gaps, omissions, challenges and opportunities to develop ethical policies concerning AI.
In 2023 Uruguay started a revision of its existing AI strategy, based on UNESCO’s RAM.

The country has also embarked on a revision of its existing AI framework, which includes revisiting its current sectoral policies, and institutional capacity to address the risks and benefits of AI, incorporating the RAM as a key tool in this exercise.
strengths: It has been adopted in more than 60 countries as of 2024, and Uruguay was one of the first to join this exercise.
Uruguay was a leading country in the region to consolidate a national AI strategy, which was first published in 2020.

Significantly, the country has also embarked on the design of its first comprehensive national data strategy aligned with the AI strategy revision, which showcases a holistic vision that is essential to develop ethical and policy robust frameworks.

A law passed in Parliament in October 2023 ratifies AGESIC (Agency for Electronic Government, and Information and Knowledge Society) as responsible for both the AI and national data governance strategies, a milestone in the recognition of the central role of both these issues for the country, and ho

In support of this new approach, a law that was passed in October 2023 entrusts AGESIC with the responsibility of designing, developing, implementing, and overseeing comprehensive AI and Data Strategies.
Uruguay’s robust data protection legislation, comprising laws on personal data protection and privacy, sets a high standard for data handling and user rights.
Regarding human capital, Uruguay has shown considerable progress in developing public sector capacity for AI, with AGESIC leading training programs for public officials.
Concurrently, the country’s digital infrastructure stands out regionally, marked by robust connectivity and a significant data center presence.

• Regulation for Contracting and Procurement of AI Systems: Aligned with Uruguay’s commitment to transparency and the strategic vision of its AI policy, it is imperative to establish a comprehensive policy and guidelines for the procurement of AI systems within the State.
In late 2023 and early 2024, large technology companies have adopted standards of self-regulation to provide watermarking systems for various forms of AI-generated content.
gaps: This is of crucial importance in a present state of expansion of AI and the need to spur the role of governments in the steering of AI and the consolidation of strong and diverse national ecosystems around this theme.

The explicit recognition of digital gender divide indicators needs to be further developed to better design and direct policies to address these gaps in the workforce, as well as in university enrollment and graduation figures, consistent with the UNESCO Recommendation on the Ethics of AI (2021).

DIAGNOSIS OF THE NATIONAL AI LANDSCAPE Uruguay is committed to the implementation of the UNESCO Recommendation on the Ethics of AI as part of the need to update its current AI strategy that is in force since 2020.

The current ongoing revision of the AI Strategy showcases Uruguay’s dynamic approach to AI that focuses on institutionalization, governance, respect for human rights and the need to tailor the strategy to meet the country’s vision as a powerhouse for innovation, economic growth, and legal safeguards

However, the evolving nature of AI technologies poses challenges in establishing legally binding standards and norms beyond the scope of the government, since the current strategy’s scope is limited to the public sector.
However, the effectiveness of these policies and the national data exchange framework is yet to be evaluated.
However, the effectiveness of AI-related laws in this domain remains unclear and more specific work could be accomplished.
However, this is changing to reflect Uruguay’s commitment to sustainable practices.
Despite these advancements, there is a need for a more focused emphasis on the role of AI within this strategy.
Although it currently lacks a dedicated policy for AI in cultural heritage preservation, there is interest in its potential applications.

technological_infrastructural.title: Technological and Infrastructural
findings: TECHNICAL AND INFRASTRUCTURAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND CONNECTIVITY Uruguay has approached the development of its digital infrastructure as a sustained policy priority since its first digital agenda in 2007 (which is now in its 5th edition) (Rosso Risso, 2024).
Digital infrastructure from a government policy approach has been conceived at the network, hardware, and platform level with sustained and incremental approach across the different governments.
Interoperability in digital identity platforms and services, as well as the development of the digital public health record are exemplars of digital public infrastructure at the data level.
APPLIED STANDARDS There is no systematized data for participation from the country in AI related standardization bodies.

Google’s project for the data center is situated in the Parque de las Ciencias free zone, where companies benefit from incentives that include exoneration of many different taxes (Parque de las Ciencias, n.d.).

Microsoft, on the other hand, has developed a cloud infrastructure specifically designed around AI and the Internet of Things with the installation of a dedicated lab, the fourth of its kind in the world (Uruguay XXI, 2022b).

This has significant impact on the experimentation and testing phases of several local SMEs and research groups which have been relying on this cloud infrastructure (authors’ own interviews); b) There’s a policy concerning cloud usage for public administration and management promoted by AGESIC (2022
In terms of data product scores, the total score is 69, while for data sources, it is 64.
strengths: AGESIC was responsible for the first and current Uruguayan AI strategy and is leading its revision.
Evaluating comprehensive educational reforms, particularly in coordination with ANEP, the Ministry of Education and Culture, the Ministry of Work and INEFOP, becomes imperative.
This discourse highlighted the complexities involved in balancing the innovative potential of AI with the ethical responsibility of safeguarding sensitive data.

A considerable number of participants expressed alignment with the regulatory model for AI established by the European Union, the EU AI Act, citing its structured approach based on risk levels as a potential guiding framework for Uruguay’s AI regulations.
gaps: In terms of internet access, the EUTIC highlights a marginal gender gap: 89% for men and 91% for women.
Specific data about the gender gap in mobile telephony remains unavailable.

Moreover, the EUTIC survey does not specifically distinguish rural areas, but rather differentiates the capital city, Montevideo, housing roughly half of the nation’s population, and the rest of the country, referred to as ‘Interior’.
Of these data centers, 8 function as colocation data centers, while one (Banco República’s ‘CPD Casa Central’) does not.
Uruguay does not have a specific policy solely dedicated to AI-based cloud computing.
However, no assessment of the effectiveness of such policy has been carried out.
However, in data infrastructure, the score is notably lower at a total of 20 (World Bank, n.d.).
However, there is no overarching data governance framework in the sense of a general guideline.

Beyond a purely institutional dimension, participants also emphasized the need for extensive cross-sector collaboration, highlighting challenges posed by siloed approaches within and between the public and private domains.
This new strategic approach implies a broadening of the scope needed to address challenges and unmet needs.

ort capacity of local firms. 3 In the Global Responsible AI Index, published in June 2024, Uruguay ranks 19th in a global list of 138 countries, with a total score of 44.09 out of 100. The Index sets

achievements.achievement: It has been adopted in more than 60 countries as of 2024, and Uruguay was one of the first to join this exercise.
During 2023 a public, open, and multistakeholder approach was implemented to get feedback, insights, and advice for the development of the new AI strategy in the country.

A law passed in Parliament in October 2023 ratifies AGESIC (Agency for Electronic Government, and Information and Knowledge Society) as responsible for both the AI and national data governance strategies, a milestone in the recognition of the central role of both these issues for the country, and how data and AI are interdependent and rely on comprehensive policy-making to successfully address its opportunities and challenges.

Regarding Internet usage, 90% of people aged 14 and older are users, and 83% use the Internet daily1 Moreover, Uruguay is a recognized regional leader in renewable energy usage and is evolving its approach towards integrating environmental sustainability in its AI strategy.

BUDGET Within AGESIC, resources are allocated for the review process of the AI Strategy and the development of the Observatory for AI usage in the State, as well as within the URCDP and other policies and tools deployed by this agency.
This is expected to change with the recognition of the national Law 20.2012 of 2023, on the role of AGESIC for the future strategy that will encompass both the public and the private sectors.
However, efforts are underway to explore alternatives and identify regional best practices, such as those that are being implemented by Chile.

In addition to government efforts, Civil Society Organizations (CAINFO) and Universities (UCU) with the ITAeL (Online Active Transparency Index) have implemented annual transparency reporting mechanisms linked to the Right of Access to Public Information Law 18.381 (CAINFO, 2022).
The Uruguayan state-owned telecommunications company, ANTEL, has deployed both LTE and FTTH; this last one in towns with up to 5,000 inhabitants.

From 2023 it ranks first in the region for download mobile Internet speed (Ookla, 2023), 91% of households have some form of Internet access – fixed or mobile, and 83% of inhabitants use it on a daily basis (AGESIC, 2023a).
Over these two decades several measures have been implemented to ensure connectivity and internet access for households and individuals.

The 2023 XI Illustration Award, co-organized by the Ministry of Education and Culture (MEC) and the Uruguayan Film and Audiovisual Agency (ACAU), is an example where the use of AI was enabled as one of the competing techniques (MEC, 2023a, p.

CURRICULUM CONTENT There are specific initiatives implemented by institutions such as Ceibal, incorporating AI as a subject matter in education and promoting relevant content through their platforms (Ceibal, 2022a).
“Uruguay has developed a digital platform (DP) which defines and implements standards and solutions for the development of the digital transformation of government agencies.

Microsoft, on the other hand, has developed a cloud infrastructure specifically designed around AI and the Internet of Things with the installation of a dedicated lab, the fourth of its kind in the world (Uruguay XXI, 2022b).
In 2021, the Transparency and Access to Information Index was implemented to measure transparency levels (INTAI, 2021).

As already mentioned at the beginning of this report, this law assigns the AGESIC with the task of designing and developing a national data and artificial intelligence strategy based on international standards and founded on principles such as equity, non- discrimination, accountability, transparency, audit, and safe innovation, respecting human dignity, the democratic system, and the republican form of government.

Instead, a coordinated approach with a multi-level, multi-actor approach is essential as well as learning from the initiatives and policies implemented in countries like Canada, the European Union, the United Kingdom, and China.
These guidelines should apply not only to domestic operations but also consider the global footprint of technologies deployed, including those using infrastructures based outside Uruguay.
This should cover a range of organizations, from start-ups and SMEs to well- established national and international companies.
Additionally, establishing awards for AI developments is another promising avenue.
These awards, potentially in collaboration with international organizations, could provide both recognition and incentives for companies in Uruguay that are innovating responsibly with AI.
Emphasizing responsible innovation in these awards will encourage companies to integrate ethical considerations and human rights into their AI products.
Uptime Institute Awards in Uruguay.

recommendations.title: AI Sandbox regulation
recommendations.text: AI Sandbox regulation: This process is already being developed, as mandated by Art. 75, Law 20.212 (2023). Regulating sandboxes for AI use will not only stimulate private sector innovation but will also spur public sector demand.

recommendations.title: Deep fake2 regulatory governance
recommendations.text: Deep fake2 regulatory governance: Although this theme emerged in a few discussions of the consultation process, particularly due to the increasing use of generative AI across multiple sectors. The Uruguayan political sector and public opinion are increasingly concerned about the effects of deep fakes, particularly when 2024 is an electoral year. In late 2023 and early 2024, large technology companies have adopted standards of self-regulation to provide watermarking systems for various forms of AI-generated content. Supporting these international approaches and participating in these processes, coupled with local interventions in national media environments and comprehensive digital citizenship programs and campaigns, is essential to address these concerns. 13

recommendations.title: Creating a Unit for the Development of the National AI Strategy within AGESIC
recommendations.text: Creating a Unit for the Development of the National AI Strategy within AGESIC: As part of consolidating the AI agenda and addressing the need for dedicated resources to coordinate the various components, a key recommendation is the establishment of a specialized unit within AGESIC dedicated to overseeing and managing these efforts effectively. This is partially invoked in Art. 74, Law 20.212 (2023).

recommendations.title: Coordination with Public Sector
recommendations.text: Coordination with Public Sector: The rapid evolution of AI technology presents unique challenges and opportunities for Uruguay that require a dynamic and collaborative approach to governance and regulation. Recognizing AI’s transformative impact across a broad spectrum of sectors, it is imperative for the Uruguayan government to develop a framework that can adapt to the technology’s evolving nature.

recommendations.title: Development of a National AI Dialogue mechanism
recommendations.text: Development of a National AI Dialogue mechanism: The development of a national governance ecosystem for AI in Uruguay represents a significant step towards harnessing the potential of this technology. There is a need to generate greater visibility of the stakeholders involved, their interests, as well as to promote synergies among them.

recommendations.title: Monitoring and evaluation
recommendations.text: Monitoring and evaluation: Establishing a monitoring and evaluation framework for Uruguay’s AI strategy is fundamental to the strategy’s successful implementation, sustainability, and legitimacy. This comprehensive approach involves the development of robust capabilities within AGESIC.

recommendations.title: Incentives to Improve the Data Strategy for AI
recommendations.text: Incentives to Improve the Data Strategy for AI: As Uruguay progresses in developing its national data strategy, which encompasses both public open data and personal data, its intrinsic link with the AI strategy reform needs to address protection, publication, and the re-use of data.

recommendations.title: Environmental Impact Policies
recommendations.text: Environmental Impact Policies: Although the environmental impact did not emerge as a topic of concern in the public consultation with Uruguayan stakeholders, there is an increasing role of AI in the carbon footprint and consumption of natural resources that should be acknowledged, in line with UNESCO Recommendation on the Ethics of AI (2021) Values and Principles. This is shared by the public opinion due to a large vendor’s construction of a data center in Uruguay, the first of its kind in the country.

recommendations.title: Deploying a Policy for AI Infrastructure
recommendations.text: Deploying a Policy for AI Infrastructure: The ongoing revision of Uruguay’s AI strategy and the development of a national data strategy are an essential opportunity to establish a comprehensive AI infrastructure policy, which has scope for improvement (Oxford Insights, 2023). This policy, encompassing data, hardware, data centers, and cloud, aims to support the economic, social, environmental, and ethical dimensions of AI.

recommendations.title: Strengthening Resources and Personnel
recommendations.text: Strengthening Resources and Personnel: The implementation of an expanded AI strategy requires dedicated personnel and resources within the State. AGESIC, the national focal point for the strategy, has demonstrated strong capabilities. To enhance its effectiveness, AGESIC should strengthen its human capacity to comply with the coordination, monitoring, and follow-up activities.

recommendations.title: Strengthening national ecosystem community leadership
recommendations.text: Strengthening national ecosystem community leadership: In addition to consolidating AGESIC’s capabilities, the strategy’s success hinges on broadening stakeholder engagement in a sustained manner.

recommendations.title: Participation of Women
recommendations.text: Participation of Women: Addressing the gender gap in the AI industry is a critical issue that requires comprehensive evaluation and action.

recommendations.title: Improving AI R&D Indicators with Relevant Actors
recommendations.text: Improving AI R&D Indicators with Relevant Actors: AI needs the development of specialized indicators in the field of national Research and Development (R&D), not only as a scientific or technocratic endeavor, but as one which will allow the country to consolidate a vision for the future to improve in its innovation capacity.

recommendations.title: Promoting Discussion and Implementation of Policies Aimed at Work, Talent development and Education
recommendations.text: Promoting Discussion and Implementation of Policies Aimed at Work, Talent development and Education: The new AI strategy for Uruguay should dedicate a specific section to fostering the discussion and implementation of policies focused on the transformation of work through AI and the development of talent.

recommendations.title: Deploying a Policy of Responsible Innovation
recommendations.text: Deploying a Policy of Responsible Innovation: The implementation of a Policy of Responsible Innovation is crucial for Uruguay’s private sector, encompassing SMEs and start-ups, to foster a culture of open innovation.

recommendations.title: Stimulating SME Participation in the State
recommendations.text: Stimulating SME Participation in the State: The lack of a large internal market due to the reduced size of its population, coupled with the State’s historically influential role in the economy is perceived as an opportunity to foster engagement with national companies, particularly Small and Medium-sized Enterprises (SMEs). 14 I- DIAGNOSIS OF THE NATIONAL AI LANDSCAPE Uruguay confirmed its intention to implement the UNESCO (2022b) Recommendation on the Ethics of AI through a letter signed on June 8, 2023, between the Directors of UNESCO Montevideo and the Agency for Electronic Government and the Information and Knowledge Society (AGESIC) (AGESIC, 2023e). The latter, operating under the Presidency of Uruguay, is overseeing the review of the AI Strategy and the development of the first National Data Strategy, receiving technical support from CAF and UNESCO for both initiatives. The initiative is driven by significant international changes in principles and standards, technological developments such as generative AI, and the alignment of the current Artificial Intelligence Strategy for Digital Government, effective since 2020, among other factors. In this consultation and participation process, efforts focused on aspects of institutionalization and governance of the new AI strategy, allowing room to define the alternative that best suits the country (AGESIC, 2023d). The Uruguayan State’s prior experience with AGESIC shows the possibilities within the existing framework to innovate and make institutional adjustments in line with ethical recommendations (AGESIC, 2020a). Furthermore, an article has been included in the Accountability Bill (Ley de Rendición de Cuentas, October 2023) (Law 20.212, 2023) that has assigned to AGESIC the responsibility for designing and developing AI and Data Strategies, while also advocating for the corresponding regulation. Article 13 of the Personal Data Law 18.331, 2008, was amended to enhance the right to information, and is mandatory for

rankings_indices.context: ### Page 19 18 DATA SHARING AND ACCESSIBILITY Uruguay ranks 71 out of 195 countries in the Open Data Inventory (ODIN, 2023) classification.

In the 2023 Global Gender Gap Index, composed by four dimensions: Economic Participation and Opportunity, Educational Attainment, Health and Survival, and Political Empowerment Uruguay ranks 67th and has improved 5 places compared to the 2022 edition.

3 and 4: Source PISA Report (2018) ### Page 24 23 PUBLIC ENGAGEMENT AND TRUST The country ranks 35th on the Online Service Index (OSI) –which measures a government’s capability and willingness to provide services and communicate with its citizens electronically– with a score of 0.84, holding the top position in the region (United Nations, 2022).

Regarding the Electronic Participation Index (EPI) – which evaluates the extent to which a government provides information to its constituents, involves citizens in policy design, and empowers citizens in decision-making processes– the country scored 0.50 points in 2022, occupying the 61st position.

Uruguay ranks 72nd in Data Science according to Coursera’s World Skills Report 2022 (Coursera, 2023), highlighting its position in the global educational landscape PUBLIC ACCESS TO AI EDUCATION In Uruguay there are technical courses on AI aimed to the public.
Data Governance stands as one of the four pillars in the Global Data Barometer, where Uruguay holds a score of 72.

The score for the ‘Infrastructure’ dimension in the Oxford Insights (2023) report is 56.6 points for Uruguay, with scope for improvement particularly when compared with some of the top 10 countries in this ranking (UK scored 75, the Netherlands 80.2 and Japan 79.9 in this dimension).
